" some years ago. Scarcely a carriage could pass 'without being robbed, and frequently the passengers were obliged to light
" with, and give battle to the Highwaymen, -who infested the Roads :"

AHD THE MYSTERIOUS DESCENT TO EARTH OF

THE CEKESTIaL FLAIVET J

Or, THE FIFTH OF NOVEMBER.

"Eemember, reinemb.r,
We see no reason
Guy Fawkes, Guy.
"rh© Fifth of November,
Why Gunpowder Treason
With his Lantern so sly.
Gunpowder Treason and Plot,
Should ever be forgot.
Got into Parliament House."
Pot the remainder oi this interesting metrical Legend, consult any cf the Masters BROWN, JONES, ROBINSON, SMITH,
or TOMKINS of the Metropolis.

AY. MARSHALL. II. YOUNGE. MEADOWS. SIWARD. &c
The Decorations and Mechanical Transformations, by W. BRADWEL1,.
The Dresses bv HEAD and Mrs. VT. BALDING and the Pantomime invented and arranged by

Mr. OSBALDISTON has the gratification of announcing to the Public, that in
consequence of the complete overflow to all parts of the Theatre—the enthusiastic
applause that again attended the entire performance of The HUNCHBACK—and
the brilliant success that crowned the Debut and subsequent Appearances of
that popularPlay - with the same powerful distribution of characters, will be repeated

THIS EVENING, and TO-MORROW.
T h e F a r t Of J u l i a ,
b y M i s s H E L E N F A U C I T , M« Fourth and Fifth Appearances.

with the New Comic Pantomime of HARLEQUIN GUY FAWKES, at an early
hour, and the fflelo-Dramatic Romantic Spectacle of T H E BRONZE HORSE*

" Remember, remember,
We see no reason
Quy Fawkes, Guy,
The Fifth of November,
Why Gunpowder Treason
With his Lantern so sly,
Gunpowder, Treason and Plot,
Should ever be forgot.
Got into Parliament House."

During the last Two Months, every
department of the Theatre has been,
^
and is a t the
present moment, most
tJle
actively employed *** production of the New
Operatic Romance of

QUASIlMODOs
Or, flte Gypsey Girl of Notre

name

-which w i l l he produced on T U E S D A Y N E X T , February 2nd, on a scale of
Grandeur almost unprecedented in t h e annals of Theatricals—with the whole of
the Scenery entirely new, assisted by extensive Machinery and Decorations, and
interspersed with National Dances, Processions, &c—The Drama founded on t h e
celebrated V I C T O R HUGO'S Romance of " Notre Dame."—The Overture and t h e
whole of t h e Music by t h e l a t e C A R L M A R I A V O N W E B E R . - T h e Scenery
by Marshall, assisted by Seward, W.Marshall, H . T o u n g , Thomson, Williams,
Ormithon, Saddler, Makein* &c—The Dresses by B e a d , Balding, &c.~The
Decorations, by Brad well.—The Machinery by Sloman.—The Dances by Madame
V e d y . - T h e Armour by Signor Canthini.—And t h e P i e c e produced under the
immediate direction of Mr. H . W a l l a c k .

a Grand Operatic Romance, (in Three Acti) entitled

QUASIIKIODO:

ZAZEZIZOZU!

OR. DOMINOESf C H E S S ! ! A N D C A R D S ! ! !
Having, by the Beauty of its Scenery—the Splendour of its Pageantry—its Grotesque
and Unique Effects—and its total Novelty—Created a Sensation Unparalleled in
such Productions, will, in consequence of the Enthusiasm of Crowded Audiences,
continue its Triumphant Career until further Notice.
Miss H E L E N F A U C I T
W i l l perform This Evening, Mrs. Haller in T H E S T R A N G E R ;
and To-morrow, Margaret in T h e S E P A R A T I O N .

Having, by the Beauty of its Scenery—the Splendour of its Pageantry—its Grotesque
and Unique Effects—and its total Novelty—Created a Sensation Unparalleled in
such Productions, will, in consequence of the Enthusiasm of Crowded Audiences,
continue its Triumphant Career until further Notice.

Having, by the Beauty of its Scenery—the Splendour of its Pageantry—its Grotesque
and Unique Effects—and its total Novelty—Created a Sensation Unparalleled in
such Productions, will, in consequence of the Enthusiasm of Crowded Audiences,
continue its Triumphant Career until further Notice.

Doors o p e n a tH a l f - p a s t Six, P e r f o r m a n c e t oc o m m e n c e precisely a t Seven.

DON JUARJ OF AUSTRIA!

Erery anticipation which the Lessee had formed is now most fully and unequi
vocally realiaed; and DON JUAN OF AUSTRIA stands oonfessed the most
successful Drama of the Season. The breathless anxiety with which each sue
ceeding Scene was listened to—and the intense interest it excited in every bosom,
as the Drama drew towards its conclusion, ean alone be equalled by the applause
which burst simultaneously from a most crowded and delighted audience. The
Lessee therefore seizes this opportunity of acknowledging his thanks for the
liberal support he has hitherto met with, and begs to assure his Patrons that no
exertion—no expence, shall be spared to render this Theatre worthy the high
rank it now holds. The Drama of DON JUAN of AUSTRIA will, in consequence
of its GREAT SUCCESS, be performed EVERY EVENING till further notice.

This Kveiling, TUESDAY, April 19th. 1336,

n®K
JVAN OF AUSTRIA!
Every anticipation which the Lessee had formed is now most folly and uneqn.
vocally realized; and DON JUAN OF AUSTRIA stands confessed the most
successful Drama of the Season. The breathless anxiety with which each sue
ceeding Scene is listened to—and the intense interest it excites in every bosom, ai
the Drama draws towards its conclusion, can alone be equalled by the applatut
which bursts simultaneously from crowded and delighted audiences. The
Lessee therefore seizes this opportunity of acknowledging his thanks for the
liberal support he has hitherto met with, and begs to assure his Patrons that nt
exertion—no expence, shall be spared to render this Theatre worthy the high
rank it now holds. The Drama of DON JUAN of AUSTRIA will, in consequence
of i t s G R g A T SUCCESS, beparfcrmed E V E R Y EVENING till farther notice

This^veTiiiig, WEDNESDAY, April 2Oth, 1S36,~

Doors open a t H a l f - p a s t Six. P e r f o r m a n c e t o c o m m e n c e precisely a t Seven.

D®1V JUAN OF AUSTRIA!

Every anticipation which the Lessee had formed is now most fully and unequivocally realized; and DON JUAN O F AUSTRIA stands confessed the most
successful Drama of the Season. The breathless anxiety with which each succeeding Scene is listened to—and the intense interest it excites in every bosom, as
the Drama draws towards its conclusion, can alone be equalled by the applause
which bursts simultaneously from crowded and delighted audiences. The
Lessee therefore seizes this opportunity of acknowledging his thanks for the
liberal support he has hitherto met with, and begs to assure his Patrons that no
exertion—no expence, shall be spared to render this Theatre worthy the high
rank it now holds. The Drama of DON JUAN of AUSTRIA will, in consequence
of its GREAT SUCCESS, be performed E V E R Y EVENING till further notice.
This Evening, THURSDAY, April 21st. 1S36,

JUAN
OF
AUSTRIA!
Every anticipation which the Lessee had formed is now most folly and nnean^

vocally realized; and DON JUAN OF AUSTRIA stands confessed the most
successful Drama of the Season. The breathless anxiety with which each succeeding Scene is listened to—and the intense interest it excites in every bosom & the Drama draws towards its conclusion, can alone be equalled by the applause
which bursts simultaneously from crowded and delighted audiences. Th«*
Lessee therefore seizes this opportunity of acknowledging his thanks for the
liberal support he has hitherto met with, and begs to assure his Patrons that no
exertion—no expence, shall be spared to render this Theatre worthy the hich
rank it now holds. The Drama of DON JUAN of AUSTRIA will, in consequence
of its GREAT SUCCESS, be performed E V E R Y EVENING till further notice.

T H E I M P E R I A L CORPS O F VOLUNTEERS.

having been pronounced by Public approbation, more pre-eminently successful
than any other Comic Piece produced for many years past; and the Military
Evolutions and Manoeuvres of tha FEMALE IMPERIAL CORPS OF
VOLUNTEERS, having elicited the greatest possible admiration & applause,
it is consequently announced for repetition This Evening and To-morrow.

LANCASTER.

represented by SPECIAL COMMAND OF H E R MAJESTY, still continues
its unabated career of attraction, notwithstanding the number of nights it has
already been represented to crowded audiences, and will be performed for the
twenty-sixth and twenty-seventh times, THIS EVENING & on MONDAY.

THE "ASSURANCE COMPANY"
haying been pronounced by Public approbation, more pre-eminently successful
than any other Comic Piece produced for many years past; and the Military
Evolutions and Manoeuvres of the FEMALE I M P E R I A L CORPS OF
VOLUNTEERS, having elicited the greatest possible admiration A applause,
It Is consequently announced for repetition '.to-morrow.

ZAZEZIZOZU: or, Dominoes! Chess! & Cards!
represented by SPECIAL COMMAND OF H E R KAJESTY, still continues
its unabated career of attraction, notwithstanding the number of nights it has
already been represented to crowded audiences, and will be performed for the
twenty-eighth & twenty-ninth times, THIS EVENING and TO-MORROW.

COMPANY"

having been pronounced by Public approbation, mote pre-eminently successful
than any other Comic Piece produced for many years past; and the Military
Evolutions and Manoeuvres of the FEMALE IMPERIAL CORPS OF
VOLUNTEERS, having elicited the greatest possible admiration & applause,
it will be acted for the T W E L F T H TIME, on THURSDAY.

will most positively be the L A S T SEASON t h a t Mr. C H A R L E S K E M B L E will
appear on the Stage; during which period, h e will act t h a t varied round of
Characters for which he has been so eminently distinguished.

Mr. C H A R L E S

KEfflBLE:

•

The Lessee begs to remind the Patrons of the NATIONAL DRAMA, that this
will most positively be the LAST SEASON that Mr. CHARLES KEMBLE will
appear on the Stage; daring which period, he will act that varied round of
Characters for which he has been so eminently distinguished.
The Comic Pantomime of

GUY FAWKES; or, the FIFTH of NOVEMBER!
was nevermore successful on itsfirstrepresentations than now;and will consequently
be repeated This Evening, and (for the 60th and last time) on Monday.

This Evening, THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 33, 1836,

this

" Many of your Lordships must recollect what used to take place on the Highroads in the Neighbourhood of this Metropolis
"some years ago. Scarcely a carriage could pass without being robbed, and frequently
the passengers were obliged to fight
Dukt
" with, and give battle to the Highwaymen, who infested the roads."

LORD BYRON'S PLAY OP W E R N E R :

In consequence oi the immense applause bestowed upon the Play of " WERNER," by a brilliant and crowded
Audience, the Public are respectfully informed that it will be repeated To-morrow Evening'.

The Part of Werner,
by Mr. M A C R E A D Y ,

K l i e JOHN.
Nothing CAN POSSIBLY exceed the Extraordinary Attraction of this
admirable Play, which, as Mr. CHARLES KEHEBLE retires from t h e
Stage after his present Engagement, can never again be acted with so Powerful
s Cast of Characters. Upwards of 3,200 Persons visited this Theatre to witness
its last representation, and many Hundreds were obliged to be denied admission.
It will therefore be repeated
On MONDAY. O c t o b e r lirth, a n d W K » N E S » A Y , t h e 19th.

its already EXTRAORDINARY and UNPRECEDENTED ATTRACTION, he has entered into such arrangements, as have
enabled him to produce an entirely New Grand Eastern Romance, founded on the Poem of the same name, by ROBERT
SOUTHEY, t s q . Poet Laureate, and entitled

thing of the kind ever yet attempted on tht British Stage, even in the most PALMY STATE OF THE DRAMA.

ADMISSION TO THE STALLS, 7s.
TO T H E PUBLIC.

its already EXTRAORDINARY and UNPRECEDENTED ATTRACTION, h e has entered into such arrangements, as have
enabled him to produce a n entirely N e w Grand Eastern Romance, founded on t h e Poem of the same name, by ROBERT
SOUTHEY, Esq. Poet Laureate, and entitled

The Lessee has the honor to announce- that, in order to add to the variety of the Entertainments of this Theatre, and to continue
it- already EXTRAORDINARY and UNPRECEDENTED ATTRACTION, he has entered into such arrangements, as have
enabled him to produce an entirely New Grand Eastern Romance, fcunded on the Poem of the same name, by ROBERT
SOUTHEY, Esq. Poet Laureate, and entitled

admission to the Theatre, on Monday Evening last, to witness the performance of
this magnificent Play, the Lessee has the honor to announce it for repetition on
Saturday next, with the same powerful Cast of Characters, as before represented

TRIUMPHAL E N T R Y of THALAR A into the CITY OP THE ISLES!

JULIUS

CJESAR:

In consequence of the crowds of persons who were disappointed in gaining
admission to the Theatre, on Monday Evening last., to witness the performance of
this magnificent Play, the Lessee has the honor to announce it for repetition
To-morrow, and on Thursday next, with the same powerful Cast of Characters,
as before represented.

AND

So great is the demand for Places to witness the
LAST P E B F O R M A N C E S of Mr. C H A R L E S
KEMBLE, previously t o his F I N A L R E T I R E M E N T F R O M T H E STAGE, t h a t it is deemed
expedient t o delay the production of Mr. E. L.
B U L W E R ' s N e w P l a y of The

DUCHESS de LA VALLIERE
until after Christmas, when it will be produced
with such attention to the elegance, correctness,
and magnificence of Scenery y Costume, & c , as
has never before been witnessed a t any Theatre
in England.

AND

So great is the demand for Places to witness the
LAST PERFORMANCES of Mr. CHARLES
KEMBLE, previously to his FINAL RETIREM E N T FROM T H E STAGE, that it is deemed
expedient to delay the production of Mr. E. L.
BULWEB's New Play of The

DUCHESS de LA VALLIERE
until after Christmas, when it will be produced
with such attention to the elegance, correctness,
and magnificence of Scenery. Costume, & a , as
has never before been witnessed a t any Theatre
in England.
On MONDAY, December 26th, 1836,—A

NEW

GRAND COMIC

Christmas Pantomime!
the production of which, will be diligently attended to in every department, with every possible exertion, and aided b y all
those peculiar facilities for which this Theatre has ever been so pre-eminently renowned.

%W The Public are respectfully informed, that, for the accomodation of a number
of Ladies and Gentlemen who have not been able to procure places in the Boxes,
some additional Stalls have been made, and the Orchestra will for this Evening
be occupied by a part of the Audience, and the Symphonies between the Acts be
played behind the Scenes.

The superior facilities which this Theatre possesses above all others in the production of Comic Pantomimes, was never more fully and firmly established, than
in the universal applause, bestowed each night, by a most Crowded Auditory, on
theNewComicPantomime of HARLEQUIN A, GEORGEY B A R N W E L L ! or,the
London Prentice ; the success of which, equal to that of any former period, fully
authorizes the announcement of its repetition forEvery Evening until farther notice
